questions.question_text: Which technique removes the outermost label of an MPLS-tagged packet before the packet is forwarded to an adjacent LER?

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: B
Penultimate hop popping (PHP) is a function performed by certain routers in an MPLS enabled network. It refers to the process whereby the outermost label of an MPLS tagged packet is removed by a label switch router (LSR) before the packet is passed to an adjacent label edge router (LER).

Selected Answer: B
B is corerct

questions.question_text:
//IMG//
Refer to the exhibit. An administrator wanted to make R1 always elected as DR, R2 as BDR, and R3 as DROTHER but could not achieve the desired results. Which two configurations resolve the issue? (Choose two.)

choices.B: On the R1 F0/0 interface, configure OSPFpriority to 202.
choices.A: On the R3 F0/0 interface, configure OSPFpriority to 201.
choices.D: On the R1 F0/0 interface, configure OSPFpriority to 255.
choices.C: On the R2 F0/0 interface, configure OSPFpriority to 200.
choices.E: On the R2 F0/0 interface, configure OSPFpriority to 201.

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: DE
As one guy earlier said:
 don't forget to smoke before the exam ;)

Selected Answer: DE
Agree its DE..the make sure R1 is 'Always' the DR then use the highest possible priority.

Selected Answer: DE
D & E are correct
Why is it E. and not C.?

comments.content: not necessarily, B&E is also a valid option but its always a best pratice to put the DR with a high number so D is better option than B in this case, just that.

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: DE
This is a very stupid questions...

Selected Answer: DE
D&E are correct

Selected Answer: DE
D&E are correct

Selected Answer: CD
To make R1 "ALWAYS" the DR set it better to 255.
Also set the R2 with priority of 200 very high.
Let R3 with defauklt priority of "1".
If you really not want to be elected set the priority to "0". But this is not an option with this question.

comments.content:
I mean D & E
Set R2 to 201.

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: A
0. Emergency
1. Alert
2. Critical
3. Error
4. Warning
5. Notice
6. Informational
7. Debug

Selected Answer: A
A is correct

Selected Answer: A
A is correct

questions.question_text:
//IMG//
Refer to the exhibit. A network engineer lost remote access to the router due to a network problem. The engineer used the console to access the router and noticed continuous logs on the console terminal. Which configuration limits the number of log messages on the console to critical and higher severity level messages?

//IMG//
Refer to the exhibit. R3 is learning the 1.0.0.0/24 route through OSPF instead of EIGRP. Which action causes R3 to choose EIGRP to reach the 1.0.0.0/24 network?

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: D
Must make OSPF AD more than EIGRP External 170

Selected Answer: D
While it's true that making the OSPF AD higher solves the problem, making the external EIGRP AD lower would also work.

Selected Answer: D
D is corerct
In this scenario EIGRP AD is 170, if we make OSPF AD higher, R3 would prefer EIGRP instead.

Selected Answer: D
D is corerct

Selected Answer: D
Notice the "no exec" command on R3. so D its the right one.

Selected Answer: D
Agree answer is D

Selected Answer: D
no Exec command on R3 stopping telnet

choices.A: Allow to use the ssh -| admin 10.0.0.1 command on the switch.
choices.D: Allow the inbound connection via the exec command on R3.
choices.C: Add the transport input telnet command on R3.
choices.B: Add the login admin command on the switch.

questions.question_text:
//IMG//
Refer to the exhibit. A network engineer cannot remote access R3 using Telnet from switch S1. Which action resolves the issue?
